docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Pox on Stem Cell Research,'' by Deborah Blum (Op-Ed, Aug. 1): The seemingly eternal conflict between faith and medical progress appears to be undergoing positive changes. No longer is it necessary, except for a small percentage of religious practitioners, to hold God responsible for illness.
docs.abstract: Eight letters comment on Deborah Blum Aug 1 Op-Ed on current impasse over embryonic stem cell research; Leonore Brooks says research should be fully supported by government; Germaine Wensley says California Nurses for Ethical Standards agrees with Pres Bush's veto of research; Lonny R Levin disputes Blum's comparison examples of medical progress through history; Phillip Certain says advances in stem cell research will be result of long, slow slog typical of any research; Bradford W Short says it is scientists whose discoveries defined life that Pres Bush feels is being violated by stem cell research; Ginger Nathanson says countries with less restrictive stem cell research laws will be leaders in new medical discoveries; Fank Heynick agrees that there should be no religiously based restrictions on stem cell research; Robert Lehrman says those who value life should rejoice that human embryo evades complete destruction with stem cell research; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: The trial of a new drug in London that nearly killed six men has revealed a testing system that seems better at bringing drugs to market than protecting human safety.

headline.main: Inquiries in Britain Uncover Loopholes in Drug Trials
headline.print_headline: Inquiries in Britain Uncover Loopholes in Drug Trials

docs.snippet: The trial of a new drug in London that nearly killed six men has revealed a testing system that seems better at bringing drugs to market than protecting human safety.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. James H. Jandl helped explain the actions of red blood cells and wrote an authoritative reference work on blood and blood disorders.

headline.main: James H. Jandl, 80, Top Harvard Hematology Researcher, Dies
headline.print_headline: James H. Jandl, 80, of Harvard, A Top Hematology Researcher

docs.snippet: Dr. James H. Jandl helped explain the actions of red blood cells and wrote an authoritative reference work on blood and blood disorders.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is a sad reflection of the world's priorities that so much effort has been devoted to finding a way to produce a tastier low-fat ice cream that most likely will do little to stem the rising tide of obesity in this country (''Creamy, Healthier Ice Cream? What's the Catch?'' July 26). Yet scientists have not yet developed effective vaccines against diseases such as malaria and AIDS, which largely affect poor nations struggling to provide even minimal sustenance to their people.
docs.abstract: Lynn Jaffe letter bemoans amount of effort that is expended on producing tastier low-fat ice cream in world where illness and poverty are rampant (July 26 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     It is a sad reflection of the world's priorities that so much effort has been devoted to finding a way to produce a tastier low-fat ice cream that most likely will do little to stem the rising tide of obesity in this country...

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students take part in a "jigsaw" discussion on the ways in which human health and life expectancy have changed over the past century. For homework, they write essays examining how increasing rates of obesity might affect life expectancy in the future.

byline.original: By ANNISSA HAMBOUZ and BRIDGET ANDERSON

docs.lead_paragraph: It took six months and an investigation with a number of twists and turns to determine what made many American Legionnaires sick in 1976.

headline.main: In Philadelphia 30 Years Ago, an Eruption of Illness and Fear
headline.print_headline: In Philadelphia 30 Years Ago, An Eruption of Illness and Fear

docs.snippet: It took six months and an investigation with a number of twists and turns to determine what made many American Legionnaires sick in 1976.

docs.lead_paragraph: In late July 1976, American Legionnaires returning from a state convention in Philadelphia began to fall ill with mysterious symptoms: pneumonia and fevers topping 107 degrees.

headline.main: MEDICINE THEN AND NOW: Legionnaires' Disease THE DOCTOR'S WORLD; In Philadelphia 30 Years Ago, An Eruption of Illness and Fear

docs.snippet: In late July 1976, American Legionnaires returning from a state convention in Philadelphia began to fall ill with mysterious symptoms: pneumonia and fevers topping 107 degrees.
